'''Hemlocks''' were a type of wildflower<ref group="note>Not to be confused with the unrelated tree of the same name, which appears in some adaptations.</ref> strongly associated with the meeting of [[Beren]] and [[Lúthien]], most famously in the [[song of Beren and Lúthien|poem]] sung by [[Aragorn]].<ref>{{Cite DTP|LR 1.11.139}}</ref>

They also grew in the Old Forest.<ref>{{Cite DTP|LR 1.06.023}}</ref>

==Inspiration==
Tolkien's choice for hemlocks in the story of Beren and Lúthien was based on a time during [[World War I]], when he was stationed at Yorkshire. Near the village of Roos there was was a woodland glade filled with hemlocks.<ref name=flora>Walter S. Judd & Graham A. Judd (2017), ''[[Flora of Middle-Earth|Flora of Middle-Earth: Plants of J.R.R. Tolkien's Legendarium]]'', pp. 184-187</ref><ref>{{L|165}}</ref><ref>{{L|257}}</ref><ref>{{L|340}}</ref>

There is debate around the exact type of hemlock that inspired Tolkien, since while the plant most commonly known as hemlock (''Conium maculatum'') matches the description, its unpleasant odours possibly don't.<ref name=flora/> [[The Plants of Middle-earth]] posits that it is cow parsley (''Anthriscus sylvestris'') <ref>Dinah Hazell (2007), ''[[The Plants of Middle-earth]]'', p. 54</ref>, which [[Tolkien and the Great War]] agrees with. In any case, according to his son Christopher, Tolkien himself “regarded the restriction of a vernacular name to this or that species within a large group of plants not easily distinguishable to the eye as the pedantry of popularizing botanists—who ought to content themselves with the Linnean names.”<ref>[[John Garth]] (2003), ''[[Tolkien and the Great War]]'', p. 238</ref>
==Portrayal in adaptations==
'''1984-1997: ''[[Middle-earth Role Playing]]''''' 
:'''''Water Hemlocks''''' ([[Sindarin|S.]] ''Ulucthond'', [[Quenya|Q.]] ''Ulcasunda'') were a type of hemlock described in the game's books, which grew in Wetlands. They were compared to parsnips, having a tuber like it and turnips, though this one was poisonous. The juice from its root could be mixed with its antidote, the curoloth flower, to make a powerful poison to apply on blades, fittingly called ''blade hemlock''. <ref>{{ICE|2026}}, pp. 143-144</ref>
